article:
{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Marengo |partof=the War of the
Second Coalition |image= |caption=Louis-FranÃ§ois Lejeune: The Battle of Marengo.
Scene of the battle in which Napoleon, followed by some generals, advances on
horseback from the left towards the centre of the image. Behind him, a regiment
confronts in line the head of the Austrian pursuit column, while Desaix is being
mortally wounded at the head of his men. Further to the right, General Zach is
captured by some cavalrymen and General Saint-Julien tries to escape the same
fate. In the background General Kellermann conducts his famous cavalry charge in
the flank of the Austrians. Behind all the action lies the village of Spinetta,
in front of the Apennines. |date=14 June 1800 |place=Spinetta Marengo,
Alessandria, Piedmont, present-day Italy |coordinates= |result=Decisive French
victory |combatant1= French Republic |combatant2=
Habsburg Monarchy |commander1=Napoleon Bonaparte Louis Desaix
|commander2=Michael von Melas Peter Ott |strength1=24,000 24 guns BenoÃ®t, p. 117 |strength2=22,000 55 guns |casualties1=1,100 killed 3,600 wounded 900 missing or
captured BenoÃ®t, p. 122 'Total:
5,600' Chandler, David G.. The Campaigns of Napoleon, New York, 1966, ISBN
0-02-523660-1, p. 296, gives: 25% total casualties. |casualties2=1,000
killed 5,500 wounded 2,900 captured 15 guns captured 40 colours
captured 'Total: 9,400' Chandler, David G.. The
Campaigns of Napoleon, New York, 1966, ISBN 0-02-523660-1, p. 296, gives: 15
colours, 40 guns, 8,000 captured and 6,000 killed. Asprey, Robert. The Rise of
Napoleon Bonaparte, Basic Books, 2001, ISBN 0-465-04881-1, p. 387, gives: 6,000
killed or wounded and another 6,000 captured; 15 flags, 40 cannon. }}



The 'Battle of Marengo' was fought on 14 June 1800 between French forces under
Napoleon Bonaparte and Austrian forces near the city of Alessandria, in
Piedmont, Italy. The French overcame General Michael von Melas's surprise attack
near the end of the day, driving the Austrians out of Italy, and enhancing
Napoleon's political position in Paris as First Consul of France in the wake of
his coup dâÃ©tat the previous November. Hollins, Encyclopedia, pp.
605â606

Surprised by the Austrian advance toward Genoa in mid-April 1800, Bonaparte had
hastily led his army over the Alps in mid-May and reached Milan on 2 June. After
cutting Melasâs line of communications by crossing the river Po and defeating
[[Feldmarschallleutnant]] (FML) Peter Karl Ott von BÃ¡torkÃ©z at Montebello on 9
June, the French closed in on the Austrian army, which had massed in
Alessandria. Deceived by a local double agent, Bonaparte dispatched large forces
to the north and south, but the Austrians launched a surprise attack on 14 June
against the main French army under General Louis Alexandre Berthier. Hollins, Encyclopedia, p. 606

Initially, their two assaults across the Fontanone stream near Marengo village
were repelled, and General Jean Lannes reinforced the French right. Bonaparte
realised the true position and issued orders at 11:00 am to recall the
detachment under [[GÃ©nÃ©ral de Division]] (GdD) Louis Desaix, while moving his
reserve forward. On the Austrian left, Ottâs column had taken Castel Ceriolo,
and its advance guard moved south to attack Lannesâs flank. Melas renewed the
main assault and the Austrians broke the central French position. By 2:30 pm the
French were withdrawing and Austrian dragoons seized the Marengo farm. Bonaparte had by then arrived with the reserve, but
Berthierâs troops began to fall back on the main vine belts. Knowing Desaix was
approaching, Bonaparte was anxious about a column of Ottâs soldiers marching
from the north, so he deployed his Consular Guard infantry to delay it. The
French then withdrew steadily eastward toward San Giuliano Vecchio as the
Austrians formed a column to follow them in line with Ottâs advance in the
northern sector.

Desaixâs arrival around 5:30 pm stabilised the French position as the 9Ã¨me
LÃ©gÃ¨re (9th Light Infantry) delayed the Austrian advance down the main road and
the rest of the army re-formed north of Cascina Grossa. As the pursuing Austrian
troops arrived, a mix of musketry and artillery fire concealed the surprise
attack of [[Brigadier General|GÃ©nÃ©ral de Brigade]] (GdB) FranÃ§ois Ãtienne de
Kellermannâs cavalry, which threw the Austrian pursuit into disordered flight
back into Alessandria, with about 9,400 killed, wounded, or captured. The French
casualties were considerably fewer, but included Desaix. The whole French line
chased after the Austrians to seal une victoire politique (a political victory)
that secured Bonaparteâs grip on power after the coup. It would be followed by a
propaganda campaign, which sought to rewrite the story of the battle three times
during Napoleonâs rule.
